# **THE REPETITIONS **

Â 

Readers of the PaÌ„li suttas are invariably irked, and sometimes dismayed, by the ponderous repetitiveness of the texts. In SN these are more blatant than in the other NikaÌ„yas, even to the extent that in whole vaggas the suttas might differ from one another only in regard to a single word or phrase. Besides this type of reiterative pattern, we also come across the liberal use of stock definitions, stereotyped formulas, and pericopes typical of the NikaÌ„yas as a whole, stemming from the period when they were transmitted orally. It is difficult to tell how much of the repetition stems from the Buddha himself, who as an itinerant teacher must have often repeated whole discourses with only slight variations, and how much is due to zealous redactors eager to ring every conceivable change on a single idea and preserve it for posterity. It is hard, however, not to suspect that the latter have had a heavy hand in the redaction of the texts.

Â 

To avoid excessive repetitiveness in the translation I have had to make ample use of elisions. In this respect I follow the printed editions of the PaÌ„li texts, which are also highly abridged, but a translation intended for a contemporary reader requires still more compression if it is not to risk earning the readerâ€™s wrath. On the other hand, I have been keen to see that nothing essential to the original text, including the flavour, has been lost due to the abridgement. The ideals of considerateness to the reader and fidelity to the text sometimes make contrary demands on a translator.

Â 

The treatment of repetition patterns in which the same utterance is made regarding a set of items is a perpetual problem in translating PaÌ„li suttas. When translating a sutta about the five aggregates, for example, one is tempted to forgo the enumeration of the individual aggregates and instead turn the sutta into a general statement about the aggregates as a class. To my mind, such a method veers away from proper translation towards paraphrase and thus risks losing too much of the original text. My general policy has been to translate the full utterance in relation to the first and last members of the set, and merely to enumerate the intermediate members separated by ellipsis points. Thus, in a sutta about the five aggregates, I render the statement in full only for form and consciousness, and in between have â€œfeeling â€¦ perception â€¦ volitional formations â€¦,â€ implying thereby that the full statement likewise applies to them. With the bigger sets I often omit the intermediate terms, rendering the statement only for the first and last members.

Â 

This approach has required the frequent use of ellipsis points, a practice which also invites criticism. Several consulting readers thought I might improve the aesthetic appearance of the page \(especially in Part IV\) by rephrasing repetitive passages in a way that would eliminate the need for ellipsis points. I accepted this suggestion in regard to repetitions in the narrative framework, but in texts of straight doctrinal exposition I adhered to my original practice. The reason is that I think it an important responsibility of the translator, when translating passages of doctrinal significance, to show exactly where text is being elided, and for this ellipsis points remain the best tool at hand.

Â 





# **DHAMMA **

Â 

Rather than embark on the quest for a single English rendering that can capture all the meanings of this polyvalent PaÌ„li word, I have settled for the more pragmatic approach of using different renderings intended to match its different applications.10 When the word denotes the Buddhaâ€™s teaching, I have retained the PaÌ„li â€œDhamma,â€ for even â€œteachingâ€ fails to convey the idea that what the Buddha teaches as the Dhamma is not a system of thought original to himself but the fundamental principles of truth, virtue, and liberation discovered and taught by all Buddhas throughout beginningless time. This is the Dhamma venerated by the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, which they look upon as their own standard and guide \(see **6:2**\). which they look upon as their own standard and guide \(see 6:2\). From an internal â€œemicâ€ point of view, the Dhamma is thus more than a particular religious teaching that has appeared at a particular epoch of human history. It is the timeless law in which reality, truth, and righteousness are merged in a seamless unity, and also the conceptual expression of this law in a body of spiritual and ethical teachings leading to the highest goal, NibbaÌ„na, which is likewise comprised by the Dhamma. The word â€œDhamma,â€ however, can also signify teachings that deviate from the truth, including the erroneous doctrines of the â€œoutsideâ€ teachers. Thus the Jain teacher NiganÌ£tÌ£ha NaÌ„taputta is said to â€œteach the Dhamma to his disciplesâ€ \(IV 317,25\)â€”certainly not the Buddhaâ€™s teaching.

Â 

In one passage I render Dhamma as â€œrighteousnessâ€ \(at the Se counterpart of IV 303,21\). This is in the epithet *dhammaraÌ„jaÌ„* used for a universal monarch, where â€œking of righteousnessâ€ fits better than â€œking of the Dhamma,â€ the significance the epithet has relative to the Buddha. The corresponding adjective, *dhammika*, is â€œrighteous.â€

Â 

When *dhamma* occurs as a general term of reference, often in the plural, I usually render it â€œthings.â€ As such, the word does not bear the narrow sense of concrete material objects but includes literally *every-thing*, such as qualities, practices, acts, and relationships. Thus the four factors of stream-entry are, as *dhammas*, things; so too are the twelve factors of dependent origination, the five aggregates, the six pairs of sense bases, and the diverse practices leading to enlightenment. Used in the plural, *dhammaÌ„* can also mean teachings, and so I render it at III 225,9 foll., though the exact sense there is ambiguous and the word might also mean the things that are taught rather than the teachings about them. One expression occurring in two suttas \(II 58,3â€“4; IV 328,21â€“22\), *iminaÌ„ dhammena*, can be most satisfactorily rendered â€œby this principle,â€ though here *dhamma* points to *the* Dhamma as the essential teaching. Again, at I 167,9 \(= I 168,25, 173,10\), we have *dhamme sati*, â€œwhen this principle exists,â€ a rule of conduct followed by the Buddha.

Â 

When plural *dhammaÌ„* acquires a more technical nuance, in contexts with ontological overtones, I render it â€œphenomena.â€ For instance, *patÌ£icca-samuppannaÌ„ dhammaÌ„* are â€œdependently arisen phenomenaâ€ \(II 26,7\), and each of the five aggregates is *loke lokadhamma*, â€œa world-phenomenon in the worldâ€ that the Buddha has penetrated and taught \(III 139,22 foll.\). When the word takes on a more psychological hue, I render it â€œstates.â€ The most common example of this is in the familiar pair *kusalaÌ„ dhammaÌ„*, wholesome states, and *akusalaÌ„ dhammaÌ„*, unwholesome states \(found, for example, in the formula for right effort; V 9,17â€“27\). The enlightenment factor *dhammavicaya-sambojjhanÌ‡ga* is said to be nurtured by giving careful attention to pairs of contrasting mental states \(among them wholesome and unwholesome states; V 66,18\), and thus I render it â€œthe enlightenment factor of discrimination of states.â€ But since the *dhammas* investigated can also be the four objective supports of mindfulness \(V 331â€“32\), *dhammavicaya* might have been translated â€œdiscrimination of phenomena.â€ Sometimes *dhammaÌ„* signifies traits of character more persistent than transient mental states; in this context I render it â€œqualities,â€ e.g., MahaÌ„kassapa complains that the bhikkhus â€œhave qualities which make them difficult to admonishâ€ \(II 204,3â€“4\).

Â 

As a sense base and element, the *dhammaÌ„yatana* and *dhammadhaÌ„tu* are the counterparts of the *manaÌ„yatana*, the mind base, and the *manoviÃ±Ã±aÌ„nÌ£adhaÌ„tu*, the mind-consciousness element. The appropriate sense here would seem to be that of ideas and mental images, but the commentaries understand *dhammas* in these contexts to include not only the objects of consciousness but its concomitants as well. Thus I translate it â€œmental phenomena,â€ which is wide enough to encompass both these aspects of experience. As the fourth *satipatÌ£tÌ£haÌ„na*, objective base of mindfulness, *dhammaÌ„* is often translated â€œmind-objects.â€ So I rendered it in MLDB, but in retrospect this seems to me unsatisfactory. Of course, any existent can become an object of mind, and thus all *dhammas* in the fourth *satipatÌ£tÌ£haÌ„na* are necessarily mind-objects; but the latter term puts the focus in the wrong place. I now understand *dhammas* to be phenomena in general, but phenomena arranged in accordance with the categories of *the* Dhamma, the teaching, in such a way as to lead to a realization of the essential Dhamma embodied in the Four Noble Truths.

Â 

Finally, *-dhamma* as a suffix has the meaning â€œis subject toâ€ or â€œhas the nature of.â€ Thus all dependently arisen phenomena are â€œsubject to destruction, vanishing, fading away, and cessationâ€ \(*khayadhamma*, *vayadhamma*, *viraÌ„gadhamma*, *nirodhadhamma*; II 26,9 foll.\). The five aggregates are â€œof impermanent nature, of painful nature, of selfless natureâ€ \(*aniccadhamma*, *dukkhadhamma*, *anattadhamma*; III 195â€“96\).

Â 





# **SANÌ‡KHAÌ„RAÌ„ **

Â 

In MLDB I had changed Ven. Ã‘aÌ„nÌ£amoliâ€™s experimental rendering of *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* as â€œdeterminationsâ€ back to his earlier choice, â€œformations.â€ Aware that this word has its own drawbacks, in preparing this translation I had experimented with several alternatives. The most attractive of these was â€œconstructions,â€ but in the end I felt that this term too often led to obscurity. Hence, like the land-finding crow which always returns to the ship when land is not close by \(see Vism 657; Ppn 21:65\), I had to fall back on â€œformations,â€ which is colourless enough to take on the meaning being imparted by the context. Sometimes I prefixed this with the adjective â€œvolitionalâ€ to bring out the meaning more clearly.

Â 

*SanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* is derived from the prefix *samÌ£* \(= con\), â€œtogether,â€ and the verb *karoti*, â€œto make.â€ The noun straddles both sides of the active-passive divide. Thus *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* are both things which put together, construct, and compound other things, *and* the things that are put together, constructed, and compounded.

Â 

In SN the word occurs in five major doctrinal contexts:

Â 

\(1\) As the second factor in the formula of dependent origination, *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* are the kammically active volitions responsible, in conjunction with ignorance and craving, for generating rebirth and sustaining the forward movement of samÌ£saÌ„ra from one life to the next. *SanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* is synonymous with *kamma*, to which it is etymologically related, both being derived from *karoti*. These *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* are distinguished as threefold by their channel of expression, as bodily, verbal, and mental \(II 4,8â€“10, etc.\); they are also divided by ethical quality into the meritorious, demeritorious, and imperturbable \(II 82,9â€“13\). To convey the relevant sense of *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* here I render the term â€œvolitional formations.â€ The word might also have been translated â€œactivities,â€ which makes explicit the connection with *kamma*, but this rendering would sever the connection with *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„*in contexts other than dependent origination, which it seems desirable to preserve.

Â 

\(2\) As the fourth of the five aggregates, *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* is defined as the six classes of volitions \(*cha cetanaÌ„kaÌ„yaÌ„*, III 60,25â€“28\), that is, volition regarding the six types of sense objects. Hence again I render it volitional formations. But the *sanÌ‡khaÌ„rakkhandha* has a wider compass than the *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* of the dependent origination series, comprising all instances of volition and not only those that are kammically active. In the Abhidhamma PitÌ£aka and the commentaries the *sanÌ‡khaÌ„rakkhandha*further serves as an umbrella category for classifying all mental concomitants of consciousness apart from feeling and perception. It thus comes to include all wholesome, unwholesome, and variable mental factors mentioned but not formally classified among the aggregates in the Sutta PitÌ£aka.

Â 

\(3\) In the widest sense, *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* comprises all conditioned things, everything arisen from a combination of conditions. In this sense all five aggregates, not just the fourth, are *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* \(see III 132,22â€“27\), as are all external objects and situations \(II 191,11â€“17\). The term here is taken to be of passive derivationâ€”denoting what is conditioned, constructed, compoundedâ€”hence I render it simply â€œformations,â€ without the qualifying adjective. This notion of *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* serves as the cornerstone of a philosophical vision which sees the entire universe as constituted of conditioned phenomena. What is particularly emphasized about *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* in this sense is their impermanence. Recognition of their impermanence brings insight into the unreliable nature of all mundane felicity and inspires a sense of urgency directed towards liberation from samÌ£saÌ„ra \(see **15:20**; **22:96**\).

Â 

\(4\) A triad of *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* is mentioned in connection with the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling: the bodily formation, the verbal formation, and the mental formation \(IV 293,7â€“28\). The first is in-and-out breathing \(because breath is bound up with the body\); the second, thought and examination \(because by thinking one formulates the ideas one expresses by speech\); the third, perception and feeling \(because these things are bound up with the mind\). Two of these termsâ€”the bodily formation and the mental formationâ€”are also included in the expanded instructions on mindfulness of breathing \(V 311,21â€“22; 312,4â€“5\).

Â 

\(5\) The expression *padhaÌ„nasanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* occurs in the formula for the four *iddhipaÌ„das*, the bases for spiritual power. The text explains it as the four right kinds of striving \(V 268,8â€“19\). I render it â€œvolitional formations of striving.â€ Though, strictly speaking, the expression signifies energy \(*viriya*\) and not volition \(*cetanaÌ„*\), the qualifier shows that these formations occur in an active rather than a passive mode.

Â 

Apart from these main contexts, the word *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ra* occurs in several compoundsâ€”*aÌ„yusanÌ‡khaÌ„ra* \(II 266,19; V 262,22â€“23\), *jiÌ„vitasanÌ‡khaÌ„ra* \(V 152,29â€“153,2\) *bhavasanÌ‡khaÌ„ra* \(V 263,2\)â€”which can be understood as different aspects of the life force.

Â 

The past participle connected with *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* is *sanÌ‡khata*, which I translate â€œconditioned.â€ Unfortunately I could not render the two PaÌ„li words into English in a way that preserves the vital connection between them: â€œformedâ€ is too specific for *sanÌ‡khata*, and â€œconditionsâ€ too wide for *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„* \(and it also encroaches on the domain of *paccaya*\). If â€œconstructionsâ€ had been used for *sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„*, *sanÌ‡khata* would have become â€œconstructed,â€ which preserves the connection, though at the cost of too stilted a translation. Regrettably, owing to the use of different English words for the pair, a critically important dimension of meaning in the suttas is lost to view. In the PaÌ„li we can clearly see the connection: the *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras*, the active constructive forces instigated by volition, create and shape conditioned reality, especially the conditioned factors classified into the five aggregates and the six internal sense bases; and this conditioned reality itself consists of *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* in the passive sense, called in the commentaries *sanÌ‡khata-sanÌ‡khaÌ„raÌ„*.

Â 

Further, it is not only this connection that is lost to view, but also the connection with NibbaÌ„na. For NibbaÌ„na is the *asanÌ‡khata*, the unconditioned, which is called thus precisely because it is neither made by *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* nor itself a *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ra* in either the active or passive sense. So, when the texts are taken up in the PaÌ„li, we arrive at a clear picture in fine focus: the active *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras* generated by volition perpetually create passive *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras*, the *sanÌ‡khata dhammas* or conditioned phenomena of the five aggregates \(and, indirectly, of the objective world\); and then, through the practice of the Buddhaâ€™s path, the practitioner arrives at the true knowledge of conditioned phenomena, which disables the generation of active *sanÌ‡khaÌ„ras*, putting an end to the constructing of conditioned reality and opening up the door to the Deathless, the *asanÌ‡khata*, the unconditioned, which is NibbaÌ„na, final liberation from impermanence and suffering.

Â 





# **NAÌ„MARUÌ„PA **

Â 

In MLDB, I also had changed Ven. Ã‘aÌ„nÌ£amoliâ€™s â€œname-and-formâ€ back to his earlier rendering, â€œmentality-materiality.â€ In some respects the latter is doctrinally more accurate, but it is also unwieldly, particularly when translating verse, and thus here I return to â€œname-and-form.â€ The compound was of pre-Buddhistic origins and is used in the UpanisÌ£ads to denote the differentiated manifestation of *brahman,* the nondual reality. For the sages of the UpanisÌ£ads, *naÌ„maruÌ„pa* is the manifestation of *brahman* as multiplicity, apprehended by the senses as diversified appearances or forms, and by thought as diversified names or concepts \(the assignment of names and concepts being understood as grounded in objective reality rather than as the end-product of a purely subjective process\). The Buddha adopted this expression and invested it with a meaning consonant with his own system. Here it becomes the physical and cognitive sides of individual existence. In the expression *bahiddhaÌ„ naÌ„maruÌ„pa*, â€œexternal name-and-formâ€ \(at II 24,2\), we seem to find a vestige of the original meaningâ€”the world as distinguished according to its appearances and namesâ€”but divested of the monistic implications.

Â 

In the Buddhaâ€™s system, *ruÌ„pa* is defined as the four great elements and the form derived from them. Form is both internal to the person \(as the body with its senses\) and external \(as the physical world\). The NikaÌ„yas do not explain derived form \(*upaÌ„daÌ„ya ruÌ„pamÌ£*\), but the Abhidhamma analyses it into some twenty-four kinds of secondary material phenomena which include the sensitive substances of the sense faculties and four of the five sense objects \(the tactile object is identified with three of the great elementsâ€”earth, heat, and airâ€”which each exhibit tangible properties\). Though I render *naÌ„ma* as name, this should not be taken too literally. *NaÌ„ma* is the assemblage of mental factors involved in cognition: feeling, perception, volition, contact, and attention \(*vedanaÌ„*, *saÃ±Ã±aÌ„*, *cetanaÌ„*, *phassa*, *manasikaÌ„ra*; II 3,34â€“35\). These are called â€œnameâ€ because they contribute to the process of cognition by which objects are subsumed under conceptual designations.

Â 

It should be noted that in the NikaÌ„yas, *naÌ„maruÌ„pa* does not include consciousness \(*viÃ±Ã±aÌ„nÌ£a*\). Consciousness is its condition, and the two are mutually dependent, like two sheaves of reeds leaning one against the other \(II 114,17â€“19\). Consciousness can operate only in dependence on a physical body \(*ruÌ„pa*\) and in conjunction with its constellation of concomitants \(*naÌ„ma*\); conversely, only when consciousness is present can a compound of material elements function as a sentient body and the mental concomitants participate in cognition. Occasionally the texts speak of the â€œdescent of consciousnessâ€ \(*viÃ±Ã±aÌ„nÌ£assa avakkanti*\) serving as a condition for name-and-form \(II 91, 14â€“15\); this means that the arrival of the current of consciousness from the past existence into the new one is the necessary condition for the arising of a new psychophysical organism at conception. Sometimes too the texts speak of the descent of name-and-form \(*naÌ„maruÌ„passa avakkanti*, II 66,12, 90,19, 101,13\); this denotes the beginning of sentient life when the current of consciousness, arriving from the previous existence, becomes established under the fresh conditions.

Â 





# **NIBBAÌ„NA, PARINIBBAÌ„NA **

Â 

As is well known, *nibbaÌ„na* literally means the extinction of a fire. In popular works on Buddhism, *nibbaÌ„na* plain and simple is often taken to signify NibbaÌ„na as experienced in life, *parinibbaÌ„na* NibbaÌ„na attained at death. This is a misinterpretation. Long ago E.J. Thomas pointed out \(possibly on the basis of a suggestion by E. Kuhn\) that the prefix *pari-* converts a verb from the expression of a state into the expression of the achievement of an action, so that the corresponding noun *nibbaÌ„na* becomes the state of release, *parinibbaÌ„na* the attaining of that state.11 The distinction does not really work very well for the verb, as we find both *parinibbaÌ„yati* and *nibbaÌ„yati* used to designate the act of attaining release, but it appears to be fairly tenable in regard to the nouns. \(In verse, however, we do sometimes find *nibbaÌ„na* used to denote the event, for example in the line *pajjotassâ€™ eva nibbaÌ„namÌ£* at v. 612c.\) Words related to both *nibbaÌ„na* and *parinibbaÌ„na* designate *both* the attaining of release during life through the experience of full enlightenment, and the attaining of final release from conditioned existence through the breakup of the physical body of death. Thus, for instance, the verb *parinibbaÌ„yati* is commonly used to describe how a bhikkhu achieves release while alive \(e.g., at II 82,20; III 54,3; IV 23,8â€“9, etc.\) and also to indicate the passing away of the Buddha or an arahant \(e.g., at I 158,23; V 161,25\).

Â 

The past participle forms, *nibbuta* and *parinibbuta*, are from a different verbal root than the nouns *nibbaÌ„na* and *parinibbaÌ„na*. The former is from *nir* \+ *vrÌ£*, the latter from *nir* \+ *vaÌ„*. The noun appropriate to the participles is *nibbuti*, which occasionally occurs in the texts as a synonym for *nibbaÌ„na* but with a function that is more evocative \(of tranquillity, complete rest, utter peace\) than systematic. \(It seems no prefixed noun *parinibbuti* is attested to in PaÌ„li.\) At an early time the two verb forms were conflated, so that the participle *parinibbuta* became the standard adjective used to denote one who has undergone *parinibbaÌ„na*. Like the verb, the participle is used in apposition to both the living Buddha or arahant \(I 1,21, 187,8\) and the deceased one \(I 122,13, 158,24\). Possibly, however, *parinibbuta* is used in relation to the living arahant only in verse, while in prose its technical use is confined to one who has expired. In sutta usage, even when the noun *parinibbaÌ„na* denotes the passing away of an arahant \(particularly of the Buddha\), it does not mean â€œNibbaÌ„na after death.â€ It is, rather, the *event* of passing away undergone by one who has already attained NibbaÌ„na during life.

Â 

The suttas distinguish between two elements of NibbaÌ„na: the NibbaÌ„na element with residue \(*sa-upaÌ„disesa-nibbaÌ„nadhaÌ„tu*\) and the NibbaÌ„naelement without residue \(*anupaÌ„disesanibbaÌ„nadhaÌ„tu* \)â€”the residue \(*upaÌ„disesa*\) being the compound of the five aggregates produced by prior craving and kamma \(It 38â€“39\). The former is the extinction of lust, hatred, and delusion attained by the arahant while alive; the latter is the remainderless cessation of all conditioned existence that occurs with the arahantâ€™s death. In the commentaries the two elements of NibbaÌ„na are respectively called *kilesaparinibbaÌ„na*, the quenching of defilements at the attainment of arahantship, and *khandhaparinibbaÌ„na* , the quenching of the continuum of aggregates with the arahantâ€™s demise. Though the commentaries treat the two NibbaÌ„na elements and the two kinds of *parinibbaÌ„na* as interchangeable and synonymous, in sutta usage it may be preferable to see the two kinds of *parinibbaÌ„na* as the events which give access to the two corresponding NibbaÌ„na elements. *ParinibbaÌ„na*, then, is the act of quenching; *nibbaÌ„na*, the state of quenchedness.

Â 

To explain the philology of a term is not to settle the question of its interpretation. What exactly is to be made of the various explanations of NibbaÌ„na given in the NikaÌ„yas has been a subject of debate since the early days of Buddhism, with the ground divided between those who regard it as the mere extinction of defilements and cessation of existence and those who understand it as a transcendental \(*lokuttara*\) ontological reality. In SN some suttas explain NibbaÌ„na as the destruction of lust, hatred, and delusion, which emphasizes the experiential psychological dimension; elsewhere it is called the unconditioned, which seems to place the stress on ontological transcendence. The TheravaÌ„da commentators regard NibbaÌ„na as an unconditioned element. 12 They hold that when NibbaÌ„na is called the destruction of the defilements \(of lust, hatred, and delusion, etc.\) and the cessation of the five aggregates, this requires interpretation. NibbaÌ„na itself, as an existent, is unborn, unmade, unbecome, unconditioned \(see Ud 80â€“81\). It is in dependence on this element \(*tamÌ£ aÌ„gamma*\), by arriving at it, that there takes place the destruction of the defilements and release from conditioned existence. NibbaÌ„na itself, however, is not reducible to these two events, which are, in their actual occurrence, conditioned events happening in time. On this interpretation, the two NibbaÌ„na elements are seen as stages in the full actualization of the unconditioned NibbaÌ„na, not simply as two discrete events.

Â 

In the present work I leave *nibbaÌ„na* untranslated, for the term is too rich in evocative meaning and too defiant of conceptual specification to be satisfactorily captured by any proposed English equivalent. I translate *parinibbaÌ„na* as â€œfinal NibbaÌ„na,â€ since the noun form usually means the passing away of an arahant \(or the Buddha\), final release from conditioned existence; sometimes, however, its meaning is ambiguous, as in the statement â€œthe Dhamma \[is\] taught by the Blessed One for the sake of final NibbaÌ„na without clinging \(*anupaÌ„daÌ„parinibbaÌ„natthamÌ£*\)â€ \(IV 48,78\), which can mean either NibbaÌ„na during life or the full cessation of existence.

Â 

The verb *parinibbaÌ„yati* perhaps could have been incorporated into English with â€œnibbanize,â€ which would be truest to the PaÌ„li, but this would be too much at variance with current conventions. Thus when the verb refers to the demise of the Buddha or an arahant, I render it â€œattains final NibbaÌ„na,â€ but when it designates the extinguishing of defilements by one who attains enlightenment, I render it simply â€œattains NibbaÌ„na.â€ We also find a personal noun form, *parinibbaÌ„yiÌ„*, which I render â€œan attainer of NibbaÌ„na,â€ as it can be construed in either sense. In prose the past participle *parinibbuta*, used as a doctrinal term, always occurs with reference to a deceased arahant and so it is translated â€œhas attained final NibbaÌ„na.â€ In verse, it can take on either meaning; when it describes a living arahant \(or the Buddha\) I translate it more freely as â€œfully quenched.â€ The unprefixed form *nibbuta* does not always carry the same technical implications as *parinibbuta*, but can mean simply â€œpeaceful, satisfied, at ease,â€ without necessarily establishing that the one so described has attained NibbaÌ„na.13 At I 24,11 and II 279,8 it has this implication; at I 236,21 it seems to mean simply peaceful; at III 43, in the compound *tadanÌ‡ganibbuta*, it definitely does not imply NibbaÌ„na, for the point there is that the monk has only approximated to the real attainment of the goal. Cognates of *parinibbaÌ„na* appear in colloquial speech with a nondoctrinal sense; for example, both *parinibbaÌ„yati* and *parinibbuta* are used to describe the taming of a horse \(at MN I 446,8â€“10\). But even here they seem to be used with a â€œloaded meaning,â€ since the horse simile is introduced to draw a comparison with a monk who attains arahantship.

Â 





# **OTHER CHANGES **

Â 

In MLDB I rendered *vitakka* and *vicaÌ„ra* respectively as â€œapplied thoughtâ€ and â€œsustained thought.â€ In this translation they become â€œthoughtâ€ and â€œexamination.â€ The latter is surely closer to the actual meaning of *vicaÌ„ra*. When *vitakka* is translated as â€œthought,â€ however, a word of caution is necessary. In common usage, *vitakka* corresponds so closely to our â€œthoughtâ€ that no other rendering seems feasible; for example, in *kaÌ„mavitakka*, sensual thought, or its opposite, *nekkhammavitakka*, thought of renunciation. When, however, *vitakka* and *vicaÌ„ra* occur as constituents of the first jhaÌ„na, they do not exercise the function of discursive thinking characteristic of ordinary consciousness. Here, rather, *vitakka* is the mental factor with the function of applying the mind to the object, and *vicaÌ„ra* the factor with the function of examining the object nondiscursively in order to anchor the mind in the object.

Â 

*Bhava*, in MLDB, was translated â€œbeing.â€ In seeking an alternative, I had first experimented with â€œbecoming,â€ but when the shortcomings in this choice were pointed out to me I decided to return to â€œexistence,â€ used in my earlier translations. *Bhava*, however, is not â€œexistenceâ€ in the sense of the most universal ontological category, that which is shared by everything from the dishes in the kitchen sink to the numbers in a mathematical equation. Existence in the latter sense is covered by the verb *atthi* and the abstract noun *atthitaÌ„*. *Bhava* is concrete sentient existence in one of the three realms of existence posited by Buddhist cosmology, a span of life beginning with conception and ending in death. In the formula of dependent origination it is understood to mean both \(i\) the active side of life that produces rebirth into a particular mode of sentient existence, in other words rebirth-producing kamma; and \(ii\) the mode of sentient existence that results from such activity.

Â 

*SakkaÌ„ya* is a term for the five aggregates as a collective whole \(III 159,10â€“13\). The word is derived from *sat* \+ *kaÌ„ya*, and literally means â€œthe existing body,â€ the assemblage of existent phenomena that serve as the objective basis of clinging. Most translators render it â€œpersonality,â€ a practice I followed in MLDB \(departing from Ven. Ã‘aÌ„nÌ£amoli, who rendered it, too literally in my view, â€œembodimentâ€\). But since, under the influence of modern psychology, the word â€œpersonalityâ€ has taken on connotations quite foreign to what is implied by *sakkaÌ„ya*, I now translate it as â€œidentityâ€ \(a suggestion made to me by Ven. Thanissaro Bhikkhu\). *SakkaÌ„ya-ditÌ£tÌ£hi* accordingly becomes â€œidentity view,â€ the view of a self existing either behind or among the five aggregates.

Â 

*NibbidaÌ„*, in MLDB, was translated â€œdisenchantment.â€ However, the word or its cognates is sometimes used in ways which suggest that something stronger is intended. Hence I now translate the noun as â€œrevulsionâ€ and the corresponding verb *nibbindati* as â€œto experience revulsion.â€ What is intended by this is not a reaction of emotional disgust, accompanied by horror and aversion, but a calm inward turning away from all conditioned existence as comprised in the five aggregates, the six sense bases, and the first noble truth. Revulsion arises from knowledge and vision of things as they really are \(*yathaÌ„bhuÌ„taÃ±aÌ„nÌ£adassana*\), and naturally leads to dispassion \(*viraÌ„ga*\) and liberation \(*vimutti*; on the sequence, see **12:23**\).

# **NOTES TO GENERAL INTRODUCTION **

# **Introduction **

Â 

The *SagaÌ„thaÌ„vagga* is so called because all the suttas in this book contain verses, at least one, usually more. The Vagga is divided into eleven samÌ£yuttas containing a total of 271 suttas. Most of these samÌ£yuttas are subdivided into several vaggas, usually of ten suttas each. In four samÌ£yuttas \(3, 4, 6, 11\), the last vagga contains only five suttas, half the standard number, and these are therefore called â€œpentadsâ€ \(*paÃ±caka*\). Four samÌ£yuttas are not divided into separate vaggas \(5, 8, 9, 10\), and thus may be considered as made up of a single vagga. I have numbered the suttas consecutively within each samÌ£yutta starting from 1, with the number within the vagga given in parenthesis. The recent PTS edition of the SagaÌ„thaÌ„vagga \(Ee2\) numbers the suttas consecutively through the entire collection, from 1 to 271.

Â 

The number of verses varies from edition to edition, depending on differences in readings and on alternative ways of grouping *paÌ„das* or lines into stanzas; for a sequence of twelve paÌ„das might be divided into either two stanzas of six lines each or three stanzas of four lines each. Ee2 is the only one that numbers the verses, and this edition has 945; of these I have not included three \(**vv. 70**, **138**, **815**\), for reasons explained in the notes \(**nn. 53**, **96**, **573**\). Many of the verses occur several times within the SamÌ£yutta NikaÌ„ya, usually within the SagaÌ„thaÌ„vagga, occasionally elsewhere, as can be seen from Concordance 1 \(A\). The verses also have extensive parallels elsewhere in the PaÌ„li Canon. A large number are shared by such texts as the Thera- and TheriÌ„gaÌ„thaÌ„s, the SuttanipaÌ„ta, the Dhammapada, and the JaÌ„takas, as well as by the other NikaÌ„yas. They are also quoted in para-canonical texts such as the *MilindapaÃ±ha*, the *PetÌ£akopadesa*, and the *NettippakaranÌ£a*. A significant number have parallels in the vast corpus of non-PaÌ„li Indian Buddhist literature, such as the Patna and GaÌ„ndhaÌ„riÌ„ Dharmapadas, the *UdaÌ„navarga*, the *MahaÌ„vastu* , and even the much later *YogaÌ„caÌ„rabhuÌ„mi*. All these â€œexternalâ€ parallels are shown in Concordance 1 \(B\). Doubtlessly some of the verses were not original to the suttas in our collection but belonged to the vast, free floating mass of Buddhist didactic verse which the compilers of the texts pinned down to specific contexts by providing them with narrative settings such as those found in the SagaÌ„thaÌ„vagga.

Â 

Of the eleven samÌ£yuttas in this Vagga, eight revolve around encounters between the Buddha \(or his disciples\) and beings from other planes of existence. Since we will repeatedly run across beings from nonhuman planes in the other Vaggas too, a short summary of the Buddhist picture of the sentient universe will help us to identify them and to understand their place in early Buddhist cosmology. \(See Table 3, which gives a visual representation of this cosmology.\)

The early Buddhist texts envisage a universe with three principal tiers subdivided into numerous planes. The lowest tier is the sense-sphere realm \(*kaÌ„madhaÌ„tu*\), so called because the driving force within this realm is sensual desire. The sense-sphere realm \(in the oldest cosmology\) contains ten planes: the hells \(*niraya*\), planes of extreme torment; the animal realm \(*tiracchaÌ„nayoni*\); the domain of *petas* or ghosts \(*pettivisaya*\), shade-like spirits subject to various kinds of misery; the human realm \(*manussaloka*\); and six sense-sphere heavens \(*sagga*\) inhabited by the *devas*, celestial beings who enjoy far greater happiness, beauty, power, and glory than we know in the human realm. Later tradition adds the *asuravisaya*, the domain of titans or antigods, to the bad destinations, though in the NikaÌ„yas they are depicted as occupying a region adjacent to the TaÌ„vatimÌ£sa heaven, from which they often launch invasions against the devas.

Â 

Above the sense-sphere realm is the form realm \(*ruÌ„padhaÌ„tu*\), where gross material form has vanished and only the subtler kinds of form remain. The realm is divided into four main tiers with several planes in each. The inhabitants of these planes are also devas, though to distinguish them from the gods of the sensuous heavens they are usually called *brahmaÌ„s*. The life spans in the various brahmaÌ„ planes increase exponentially, being far longer than those in the sensuous heavens, and sensual desire has largely abated. The prevalent mode of experience here is meditative rather than sensory, as these planes are the ontological counterparts of the four *jhaÌ„nas* or meditative absorptions. They include the five â€œPure Abodesâ€ \(*suddhaÌ„vaÌ„sa*\), spheres of rebirth accessible only to nonreturners.

Â 

Beyond the form realm lies an even more exalted sphere of existence called the formless realm \(*aruÌ„padhaÌ„tu*\). The beings in this realm consist solely of mind, without a material basis, as physical form is here entirely absent. The four planes that make up this realm, successively more subtle, are the ontological counterparts of the four *aÌ„ruppas* or formless meditative attainments, after which they are named: the base of the infinity of space, the base of the infinity of consciousness, the base of nothingness, and the base of neither-perception-nor-nonperception.

Â 

The suttas often compress this elaborate cosmology into a simpler scheme of five destinations \(*paÃ±cagati*\): the hells, the animal realm, the domain of ghosts, the human realm, and the deva world. The last includes all the many deva planes of the three realms. The first three are called the plane of misery \(*apaÌ„yabhuÌ„mi* \), the nether world \(*vinipaÌ„ta*\), or the bad destinations \(*duggati* \); the human realm and the deva planes are collectively called the good destinations \(*sugati*\). Rebirth into the plane of misery is the fruit of unwholesome kamma, rebirth into the good destinations the fruit of wholesome kamma. Beyond all realms and planes of existence is the unconditioned, NibbaÌ„na, the final goal of the Buddhaâ€™s teaching.

Â 





## **1. DEVATAÌ„SAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

*DevataÌ„* is an abstract noun based on *deva*, but in the NikaÌ„yas it is invariably used to denote particular celestial beings, just as the English word â€œdeity,â€ originally an abstract noun meaning the divine nature, is normally used to denote the supreme God of theistic religions or an individual god or goddess of polytheistic faiths. Though the word is feminine, the gender comes from the abstract suffix *-taÌ„* and does not necessarily mean the devataÌ„s are female. The texts rarely indicate their sex, though it seems they can be of either sex and perhaps sometimes beyond sexual differentiation.

Â 

For Buddhism the devas are not immortal gods exercising a creative role in the cosmic process. They are simply elevated beings, blissful and luminous, who had previously dwelt in the human world but had been reborn in the celestial planes as the fruit of their meritorious deeds. With rare exceptions they are just as much in bondage to delusion and desire as human beings, and they equally stand in need of guidance from the Enlightened One. The Buddha is the â€œteacher of devas and humansâ€ \(*satthaÌ„ devamanussaÌ„namÌ£*\), and though squarely established in the human world he towers above the most exalted deities by reason of his supreme wisdom and perfect purity.

Â 

The devas usually come to visit the Buddha in the deep stillness of the night, while the rest of the world lies immersed in sleep. The DevataÌ„samÌ£yutta gives us a record of their conversations. Sometimes the devas come to recite verses in praise of the Master, sometimes to ask questions, sometimes to request instruction, sometimes to win approval of their views, sometimes even to challenge or taunt him. On approaching they almost always bow down to him in homage, for the Buddha is their spiritual and moral superior. Not to bow down to him, as some devas do \(see **1:35**\), is provocative, a deliberate withholding of due respect.

Â 

Each of the four NikaÌ„yas opens with a sutta of deep significance. Though the first sutta of SN is very short, it is rich in implications. In this case a devataÌ„ comes to the Buddha to ask how he â€œcrossed the flood,â€ that is, how he attained deliverance, and in his reply the Buddha points to the â€œmiddle wayâ€ as the key to his attainment. This answer conveys the essential spirit of the Dhamma, which avoids all extremes in views, attitudes, and conduct. The commentary draws out the ramifications of the Buddhaâ€™s statement with a list of seven extremes, philosophical and practical, transcended by the middle way.

Â 

The following suttas in this samÌ£yutta cover a wide spectrum of subjects without any particular logic in their sequence. They range from the simple to the profound, from the commonplace to the sublime, from the humorous to the stern. The exchanges discuss such ethical practices as giving, service to others, and noninjury; the difficulties of renunciation and the life of meditation; the call for earnest effort; the sorrows of human existence and the need for deliverance. There are also suttas on the bliss and equanimity of the arahant, and a few which touch on his transcendental stature. In most suttas the prose portion serves no other function than to establish a framework for the conversation, which eventually falls away leaving only an exchange of verses with the speakersâ€™ identities understood. But we occasionally find brief stories, such as that of the female devataÌ„ who tried to seduce the bhikkhu Samiddhi \(**1:20**\), or of the â€œfaultfinding devasâ€ who accused the Buddha of hypocrisy \(**1:35**\), or of the visit paid to the Buddha by a group of devas when his foot was injured by a stone splinter \(**1:38**\).

Â 

Usually the personal identity of the devataÌ„ is not revealed. An exception is the pair of suttas where the two KokanadaÌ„ sisters, daughters of the weather god Pajjunna, visit the Buddha and praise him and his Dhamma \(**1:39â€“40**\). Sometimes verses spoken by an anonymous deity recur elsewhere with the identity specified; for example, **v. 22** reappears as **v. 461**, ascribed to MaÌ„ra the Evil One; **vv. 156â€“59** reappear as **vv. 312â€“15**, ascribed to AnaÌ„thapinÌ£dÌ£ika, the celestial reincarnation of the great philanthropist. It is also rare for the suttas to assign the devas to particular realms, but there are exceptions, such as those on the â€œextolling of the goodâ€ host of devas \(*satullapakaÌ„yikaÌ„ devaÌ„*; **1:31â€“34**, etc.\) and the one on the devas of the Pure Abodes \(*suddhaÌ„vaÌ„sakaÌ„yikaÌ„ devaÌ„*; **1:37**\). The commentary, cited in the notes, often provides more background information.

Â 

When the devataÌ„ does not ask a question but voices an opinion, a contrast is usually established between the viewpoint of the deity, generally valid from within his or her limited horizons, and the viewpoint of the Buddha, who sees things far beyond the ken of the devas \(see, e.g., **vv. 3â€“6**\). Sometimes a group of devas express their opinions, which the Buddha surpasses with his own more profound contribution \(**vv. 78â€“84**, **95â€“101**\). In several suttas the verses are not spoken in the context of a conversation but express the personal views of the deva, which the Buddha tacitly endorses \(**vv. 136â€“40**\), and two verses are simple paeans of praise to the Blessed One \(**vv. 147, 148**\). Beginning with **v. 183**, the suttas assume a standard format, with the devas posing a series of riddles which the Buddha answers to their satisfaction. A memorable example of this is the riddle about the type of killing that the Buddha approves of, to which the answer is the killing of anger \(**vv. 223â€“24**\). In one sutta we find a gentle touch of humour: a devataÌ„ has asked the Buddha a series of questions, apparently mundane in intent, but before the Blessed One can reply another devataÌ„ breaks in and gives his own answers, which remain at the mundane level. Then the Buddha replies, lifting the dialogue to the transcendent plane \(**vv. 229â€“31**\). Because of its varied content and the piquancy of its verses, within the TheravaÌ„da tradition, at least in Sri Lanka, the DevataÌ„samÌ£yutta is extremely popular as a source of texts to be drawn upon for sermons.

Â 





## **2. DEVAPUTTASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

The *devaputtas*, or â€œsons of the devas,â€ are young devas newly arisen in their respective heavenly planes; *devaduhitaÌ„s*, â€œdaughters of the devas,â€ are also mentioned in the commentary but none appear in this samÌ£yutta. The commentary says these beings are reborn spontaneously in the laps of the devas. While the devataÌ„s in the preceding samÌ£yutta remain mostly anonymous, the young devas are always identified by name, and it is surprising to find that several of themâ€”or at least their versesâ€” have already appeared in the DevataÌ„samÌ£yutta \(see **2:3**, **4**, **16**, **19**, **20**, **21**, **24**, **27**\). This suggests that the dividing line between the two classes of deities is not a hard and fast one, just as the dividing line between an adult and an adolescent is not hard and fast. A relatively large proportion of the verses in this chapter focus on the monastic training, substantially more than in the DevataÌ„samÌ£yutta. The texts themselves do not drop any hints as to why this should be so; at least there are none that are readily visible.

Â 

Several suttas raise points of special interest from a doctrinal perspective. We meet, for example, the young deva DaÌ„mali who thought that the arahant must still â€œstrive without weariness,â€ until the Buddha told him that the arahant had completed his task and need not strive further \(**2:5**\). The commentary says this sutta is almost unique in that the Buddha here does *not* speak in praise of effort. Again, we meet TaÌ„yana, whose verses on exertion are applauded by the Blessed One and, the next morning, are commended by him to the monks \(**2:8**\). The two suttas on the capture of the moon god CandimaÌ„ and the sun god Suriya include verses that must have functioned as charms for terminating lunar and solar eclipses \(**2:9**, **10**\); in Sri Lanka they are included in the *Maha Pirit Pota*, â€œThe Great Book of Protection,â€ made up of suttas and other chants recited for spiritual and physical protection. We also meet SubrahmaÌ„, whose single verse is one of the pithiest expressions in world literature of the anguish at the heart of the human condition \(**2:17**\). The story of Rohitassa, who tried to reach the end of the world by travelling, elicits from the Buddha a momentous reply about where the world and its end are ultimately to be found \(**2:26**\). In this samÌ£yutta we also meet two young devas named VenÌ£hu and Siva \(at **2:12** and **2:21**\), who may be early prototypes of the Indian gods VisÌ£nÌ£u and SÌiva \(the Sanskrit forms of their names\); our text, however, apparently dates from a period before they became the chief deities of theistic devotional Hinduism. The last sutta in the chapter \(**2:30**\) introduces us to a group of young devas who were formerly disciples of the Buddhaâ€™s rivals on the Indian scene, PuÌ„ranÌ£a Kassapa, Makkhali GosaÌ„la, and NiganÌ£tÌ£ha NaÌ„taputta, teachers whose views had been unequivocally rejected by the Buddha. It is thus perplexing that their disciples should have been reborn in heaven, especially when the first two teachers propagated such doctrines as moral anarchism and fatalism. But the conclusion reached in the sutta is that such teachers were as far from the stature of true holy men as the jackal is from the lion.

Â 





## **3. KOSALASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

This chapter introduces us to King Pasenadi of Kosala. According to the Buddhist texts, Pasenadi was deeply devoted to the Buddha and often sought his counsel, though there is no record of him reaching any stage of awakening \(and thus medieval Sri Lankan tradition holds that he was a bodhisatta, who does not attain enlightenment so that he might continue fulfilling the perfect virtues that culminate in Buddhahood\). Pasenadi had been led to the Buddha by his wife, Queen MallikaÌ„, whose devotion to the Master he had previously resented. The story of how MallikaÌ„ convinced him of the Buddhaâ€™s wisdom is related in MN No. 87; MN No. 89 gives us a moving account of the kingâ€™s last meeting with the Master when they were both in their eightieth year. The first sutta of the KosalasamÌ£yutta apparently records Pasenadiâ€™s first meeting with the Blessed One, after his confidence had been aroused by MallikaÌ„â€™s ruse. Here the Buddha is described as young, and when the king questions the claim that such a youthful ascetic can be perfectly enlightened, the Buddha replies with a series of verses that dispels the kingâ€™s doubts and inspires him to go for refuge.

Â 

Unlike the first two samÌ£yuttas, the present one employs substantial prose backgrounds to the verses, and often the stanzas merely restate metrically the moral of the Buddhaâ€™s discourse. Though the topics discussed are not especially profound, they are almost all relevant to the busy lay person faced with the difficult challenge of living a moral life in the world. Especially noteworthy is the stress they lay on the need to adhere unflinchingly to the path of rectitude amidst the worldâ€™s temptations. Several suttas \(**3:4**, **5**\) show how easy it is to fall away from righteous standards, especially in an age like the Buddhaâ€™s when, as in our own time, stiff competition for wealth, position, and power was driving hallowed ethical values out of circulation. The remedy against temptation is diligence \(*appamaÌ„da*\), and when the Buddha extols diligence to the king the word does not mean, as it does in a monastic context, constant devotion to meditation, but persistence in the performance of meritorious deeds. For a man like Pasenadi, a happy rebirth rather than NibbaÌ„na is the immediate goal.

Â 

The kingâ€™s conversation with MallikaÌ„, in which they both admit they cherish themselves more than anyone else \(**3:8**\), elicits from the Buddha a verse which gives an ethical slant to a metaphysical thesis found in the BrÌ£hadaÌ„ranÌ£yaka UpanisÌ£ad, also occurring in a conversation between husband and wife, that of all things the self is the most precious. This raises the interesting question whether the close correspondence between the two is sheer coincidence \(not impossible\) or the result of a deliberate reworking by the Buddha of the old UpanisÌ£ad. On another occasion we see the king display lack of acumen in his assessment of ascetics \(**3:11**\)â€”perhaps a hint that his commitment to the Dhamma was not unwaveringâ€”and the Buddhaâ€™s response offers astute counsel on how to judge a personâ€™s character.

Â 

In this samÌ£yutta we even find, from the Masterâ€™s golden lips, enlightened advice for losing weight \(**3:12**\), while two other suttas provide an historical perspective on the conflict between Kosala and Magadha, with reflections on war and peace \(**3:14â€“15**\). Of timely interest is the Buddhaâ€™s verse explaining to the king that a woman can turn out better than a man \(**3:16**\). Elsewhere the Buddha rejects the idea, propagated by the brahmins, that birth is an important criterion of spiritual worth, stressing instead that the true marks of spiritual nobility are ethical purity and wisdom \(**3:24**\).

Â 

A theme that recurs throughout this samÌ£yutta is the inevitability of death and the inexorable operation of the law of kamma, which ensures that good and bad actions meet with due recompense. Beings pass from bright states to dark ones and from dark states to bright ones depending on their actions \(**3:21**\). All that we take with us when we die are our good and bad deeds, and thus we should be sure to accumulate merits, for in the next world these are â€œthe support for living beingsâ€ \(**3:4**, **20**, **22**\). Among several texts on the inevitability of death, the most memorable is the last sutta in the chapter \(**3:25**\), with its startling parable of the mountains advancing from all quarters, crushing everything in their way.

Â 





## **4. MAÌ„RASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

MaÌ„ra is the Evil One of Buddhism, the Tempter and Lord of Sensuality bent on distracting aspirants from the path to liberation and keeping them trapped in the cycle of repeated birth and death. Sometimes the texts use the word â€œMaÌ„raâ€ in a metaphorical sense, as representing the inward psychological causes of bondage such as craving and lust \(**22:63â€“65**\) and the external things to which we become bound, particularly the five aggregates themselves \(**23:11â€“12**\). But it is evident that the thought world of the suttas does not conceive MaÌ„ra only as a personification of humankindâ€™s moral frailty, but sees him as a real evil deity out to frustrate the efforts of those intent on winning the ultimate goal. The proof of this lies in his pursuit of the Buddha and the arahants *after* their enlightenment, which would not be credible if he were conceived of merely as a psychological projection.

Â 

The MaÌ„rasamÌ£yutta opens in the vicinity of the Bodhi Tree soon after the Buddha has attained the supreme enlightenment. Here MaÌ„ra challenges the Blessed Oneâ€™s claim to have reached the goal. He taunts him for abandoning the path of self-mortification \(**4:1**\), tries to frighten him by assuming horrific shapes \(**4:2**\), and seeks to break his equanimity by displaying beautiful and hideous forms \(**4:3**\). For the Buddha to triumph in these contests he need only call MaÌ„raâ€™s bluff, to announce that he knows the adversary before him is none other than the Evil One. Then MaÌ„ra must disappear, frustrated and mournful.

Â 

MaÌ„ra also appears as the cynic who denies that mortals can attain perfect purity \(**4:4**, **15\)**. On several occasions he tries to confound the monks while they are listening to the Buddha speak, but each time the Buddha calls his number \(**4:16**, **17**, **19**\). On another occasion MaÌ„ra tries to tempt the Master with the lure of worldly power, but the Buddha staunchly rejects this \(**4:20**\). Especially impressive is the Godhika Sutta \(**4:23**\), where the bhikkhu Godhika, afflicted with an illness that obstructs his meditative progress, plans to take his own life. MaÌ„ra presents himself before the Buddha, pleading with him to discourage his disciple from such folly, but the Master extols devotion to the goal even at the cost of life. At the end of the sutta MaÌ„ra is searching vainly for the rebirth-consciousness of Godhika, unaware that the monk had attained NibbaÌ„na and expired â€œwith consciousness unestablished.â€

Â 

The last two suttas in this samÌ£yutta take us back to the site of the enlightenment. Here we see first MaÌ„ra and then MaÌ„raâ€™s three daughtersâ€”TanÌ£haÌ„, AratiÌ„, and RagaÌ„ \(Craving, Discontent, and Lusting\)â€”trying to find a point of vulnerability in the newly enlightened Buddha, but their efforts are in vain and they must depart disappointed \(**4:24**, **25**\).

Â 





## **5. BHIKKHUNIÌ„SAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

The BhikkhuniÌ„samÌ£yutta is a compilation of ten short suttas in mixed prose and verse, undivided into vaggas. The protagonists are all bhikkhuniÌ„s, Buddhist nuns. Though several of its thirty-seven verses have parallels in the TheriÌ„gaÌ„thaÌ„ \(mentioned in the notes and Concordance 1 \(B\)\), a substantial number are unique to this collection, while often the variations in roughly parallel versions are themselves of intrinsic interest. At least one nun in the BhikkhuniÌ„samÌ£yutta, VajiraÌ„, does not appear at all in the TheriÌ„gaÌ„thaÌ„, while the case of another nun, SelaÌ„, is problematic. A comparison between the two collections also brings to light some noteworthy differences in the ascription of authorship. Since SN and the TheriÌ„gaÌ„thaÌ„ were evidently transmitted by different lines of reciters, it was only too easy for verses to break off from their original narrative setting and merge with a different background story connecting them to a different author.

Â 

All the ten suttas are constructed according to the same pattern, a direct confrontation between MaÌ„ra and an individual nun. This structure probably accounts for the placement of the BhikkhuniÌ„samÌ£yutta immediately after the MaÌ„rasamÌ£yutta. Each sutta of this collection begins with a nun going off by herself to pass the day in solitary meditation. Then MaÌ„ra approaches her with a challengeâ€”a provocative question or a tauntâ€”intending to make her fall away from concentration. What MaÌ„ra has failed to realize is that each of these nuns is an arahant who has seen so deeply into the truth of the Dhamma that she is utterly inaccessible to his wiles. Far from being flustered by MaÌ„raâ€™s challenge, the nun promptly guesses her adversaryâ€™s identity and meets his challenge with a sharp retort.

Â 

In a dialogue that brings together the Lord of Sensuality with a solitary nun one might expect each of MaÌ„raâ€™s overtures to be aimed at sexual seduction. This, however, is so only in several suttas. The actual themes of the discourses vary widely and expose us to a broad range of perspectives on the attitudes and insights of the renunciant life. The contrast between the allurement and misery of sensual pleasures is the theme of **5:1**, **4**, and **5**. In all three cases the nuns sharply rebuke MaÌ„ra with verses that reveal their utter indifference to his solicitations.

Â 

MaÌ„raâ€™s dialogue with SomaÌ„ \(**5:2**\) voices the ancient Indian prejudice that women are endowed with â€œmere two-fingered wisdomâ€ and thus cannot attain NibbaÌ„na. SomaÌ„â€™s rejoinder is a forceful reminder that enlightenment does not depend on gender but on the mindâ€™s capacity for concentration and wisdom, qualities accessible to any human being who earnestly seeks to penetrate the truth. In **5:3**, MaÌ„ra approaches KisaÌ„gotamiÌ„, the heroine of the well-known parable of the mustard seed, trying to arouse her maternal instincts to beget another son. His challenge thus touches on sensuality only indirectly, his primary appeal being aimed at the feminine desire for children.

Â 

The last two suttas are philosophical masterpieces, compressing into a few tight stanzas insights of enormous depth and wide implications. When MaÌ„ra challenges SelaÌ„ with a question on the origins of personal existence, she replies with a masterly poem that condenses the whole teaching of dependent origination into three four-line stanzas adorned with an illuminating simile \(**5:9**\). He poses a similar problem to VajiraÌ„, who answers with a stunning exposition of the teaching of nonself, illustrating the composite nature of personal identity with the famous simile of the chariot \(**5:10**\).

Â 

Though set against a mythological background in an ancient world whose customs and norms seem so remote from our own, these poems of the ancient nuns still speak to us today through their sheer simplicity and uncompromising honesty. They need no ornamentation or artifice to convey their message, for they are sufficient in themselves to startle us with the clarity of unadorned truth.

Â 





## **6. BRAHMASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

BrahmaÌ„ was the supreme deity of early Brahmanism, conceived as the creator of the universe and venerated by the brahmins with sacrifices and rituals. Occasionally this conception of BrahmaÌ„ persists in the Buddhist canon, though as a target of criticism and satire rather than as an article of faith. In such contexts the word â€œbrahmaÌ„â€ is used as a proper name, often augmented to MahaÌ„brahmaÌ„, â€œBrahmaÌ„ the Great.â€ The Buddha reinterpreted the idea of brahmaÌ„ and transformed the single, all-powerful deity of the brahmins into a class of exalted gods dwelling in the form realm \(*ruÌ„padhaÌ„tu*\) far above the sense-sphere heavens. Their abode is referred to as â€œthe brahmaÌ„ world,â€ of which there are many, of varying dimensions and degrees of hegemony. Within their realm the brahmaÌ„s dwell in companies, and MahaÌ„brahmaÌ„ \(or sometimes a brahmaÌ„ of a more personal name\) is seen as the ruler of that company, complete with ministers and assembly. Like all sentient beings, the brahmaÌ„s are impermanent, still tied to the round of rebirth, though sometimes they forget this and imagine themselves immortal.

Â 

The path to rebirth in the brahmaÌ„ world is mastery over the jhaÌ„nas, each of which is ontologically attuned to a particular level of the form realm \(see Table 3\). Sometimes the Buddha mentions the four â€œdivine abodesâ€ \(*brahmavihaÌ„ra*\) as the means to rebirth in the brahmaÌ„ world. These are the â€œimmeasurableâ€ meditations on lovingkindness, compassion, altruistic joy, and equanimity \(*mettaÌ„*, *karunÌ£aÌ„*, *muditaÌ„*, *upekkhaÌ„*\).

Â 

The NikaÌ„yas offer an ambivalent evaluation of the brahmaÌ„s, as can be seen from the present samÌ£yutta. On the one hand, certain brahmaÌ„s are depicted as valiant protectors of the Buddhaâ€™s dispensation and devoted followers of the Master. But precisely because of their longevity and elevated stature in the cosmic hierarchy, the brahmaÌ„s are prone to delusion and conceit; indeed, they sometimes imagine they are all-powerful creators and rulers of the universe. Perhaps this dual evaluation reflects the Buddhaâ€™s ambivalent attitude towards the brahmins: admiration for the ancient spiritual ideals of the brahmin life \(as preserved in the expressions *brahmacariya* and *brahmavihaÌ„ra*\) coupled with rejection of the pretensions of the contemporary brahmins to superiority based on birth and lineage.

Â 

The most eminent of the brahmaÌ„s devoted to the Buddha is BrahmaÌ„ Sahampati, who appears several times in SN. Soon after the enlightenment he descends from his divine abode and reappears before the Blessed One to beseech him to teach the Dhamma to the world \(**6:1**\). He applauds the Buddhaâ€™s reverence for the Dhamma \(**6:2**\), extols an arahant bhikkhu on alms round \(**6:3**\), reproaches the evil Devadatta \(**6:12**\), and shows up again at the Buddhaâ€™s parinibbaÌ„na, where he recites a verse of eulogy \(**6:15**\). He will also appear in other saÌ£yuttas \(at **11:17**; eulogy \(6:15\). He will also appear in other samyuttas \(at 11:17; **22:80**; **47:18**, **43**; and **48:57**\).

Â 

BrahmaÌ„s of the deluded type are epitomized by BrahmaÌ„ Baka, who imagined himself eternal and had to be divested of this illusion by the Master \(**6:4**\). On another occasion, an unnamed brahmaÌ„ imagined he was superior to the arahants, and the Buddha and four great disciples visited his realm to make him alter his views \(**6:5**\). We also witness a contest between a negligent brahmaÌ„, stiff with pride, and two colleagues of his, devotees of the Buddha, who sweep away his illusions \(**6:6**\). The penultimate sutta shows a disciple of the past Buddha SikhiÌ„ awing a whole assembly of proud brahmaÌ„s with his display of psychic powers \(**6:14**\). This samÌ£yutta also relates the sad story of the monk KokaÌ„lika, a cohort of Devadatta, who tried to defame the chief disciples SaÌ„riputta and MoggallaÌ„na and had to reap the kammic result as a rebirth in hell \(**6:9â€“10**\). The last sutta in this collection, included here only because of BrahmaÌ„ Sahampatiâ€™s single verse, is a parallel of the death scene in the long MahaÌ„parinibbaÌ„na Sutta of the DiÌ„gha NikaÌ„ya.

## **7. BRAÌ„HMANÌ£ASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

This samÌ£yutta, recording the Buddhaâ€™s conversations with brahmins, contains two vaggas, each with a different unifying theme. In the first all the brahmins who come to the Buddha, often angry \(**7:1â€“4**\) or disdainful \(**7:7â€“9**\), are so deeply stirred by his words that they ask for ordination into the SanÌ‡gha and â€œnot long afterwardsâ€ attain arahantship. These suttas display the Buddha as the incarnation of patience and peace, capable of working, in those who would attack him, the miracle of transformation simply by his unshakable equanimity and impeccable wisdom. In this vagga we also see how the Buddha assessed the brahmin claim to superior status based on birth. He here interprets the word â€œbrahminâ€ by way of its original meaning, as a holy man, and on this basis redefines the true brahmin as the arahant. The three Vedas which the brahmins revered and diligently studied are replaced by the three *vijjaÌ„s* or true knowledges possessed by the arahant: knowledge of past births, of the laws of kammic retribution, and of the destruction of the taints \(**7:8**\). The last sutta adds a touch of humour, still recognizable today, by depicting the contrast between the oppressive cares of the household life and the untrammelled freedom of the life of renunciation \(**7:10**\).

Â 

In the second vagga the brahmins come to challenge the Buddha in still different ways, and again the Buddha rises to the occasion with his inexhaustible wit and wisdom. In this vagga, however, though the Buddha inspires in his antagonists a newly won faith, the brahmin converts do not become monks but declare themselves lay followers â€œwho have gone for refuge for life.â€

## **8. VANÌ‡GIÌ„SASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

The bhikkhu VanÌ‡giÌ„sa was declared by the Buddha the foremost disciple of those gifted with inspirational speech \(*patÌ£ibhaÌ„navantÌ„naÌ£* , at AN I 24,21\). This title accrued to him on account of his skill in composing spontaneous verse. His verses make up the longest chapter in the TheragaÌ„thaÌ„, whose seventy-one verses \(Th 1209â€“79\) closely correspond with those in the present samÌ£yutta but lack the prose frameworks. Another poem by VanÌ‡giÌ„sa, found at Sn II, 12, is not included in the present compilation but does have a counterpart in the TheragaÌ„thaÌ„.

Â 

The verses of VanÌ‡giÌ„sa are not mere metrical aphorisms \(as are so many verses in this collection\) but skilfully wrought poetic compositions that can well claim an honoured place in early Indian poetry. They also reveal, with unabashed honesty, the trials and temptations which their author faced in his career as a monk. Having an aesthetic bent of character and a natural appreciation of sensuous beauty, VanÌ‡giÌ„sa must have gone through a difficult struggle in his early days as a monk adjusting to the strict discipline required of a bhikkhu, with its training in sense restraint and vigilant control of the mind. The early suttas in this chapter \(**8:1â€“4**\) speak of his battle against sensual lust, his susceptibility to the charms of the opposite sex, and his firm determination not to succumb but to continue bravely along the path laid down by his Master. They also tell of his proclivity to pride, no doubt based on his natural talent as a poet, and of his endeavour to subdue this flaw of character. Later in his monastic career, apparently after he gained a greater degree of self-mastery, he often extolled the Buddha in verse, and on one occasion the Blessed One requested him to compose extemporaneous verses \(**8:8**\). In other poems he praises the great disciples SÌ„riputta, MoggallÌ„na, and KonÌ£dÌ£aÃ±Ã±a \(**8:6**, **9**, **10**\). The last poem in the saÌ£yutta, partly autobiographical, concludes with a declaration that the author has become an arahant equipped with the three true knowledges and other spiritual powers \(**8:12**\).

## **9. VANASAMÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

This samÌ£yutta consists of fourteen suttas most of which are constructed according to a stereotyped pattern. A bhikkhu is living alone in a woodland thicket, where he should be meditating ardently, but human weakness gets the better of him and causes him to swerve from his religious duties. Then a devataÌ„ dwelling in the thicket takes compassion on him and chides him in verse, seeking to reawaken his sense of urgency. Apparently these devataÌ„s are not celestial beings, like those we meet in the DevataÌ„samÌ£yutta, but dryads or fairies, and they seem to be feminine. On a few occasions the devataÌ„ errs in her assessment of the bhikkhu â€™s behaviour. Thus in **9:2** the devatÌ„comes to reproach the bhikkhu for taking a nap, unaware he has already attained arahantship, and in **9:8** for associating too closely with a woman, again unaware the bhikkhu is an arahant \(according to the commentary\). In **9:6**, a devataÌ„ from the TaÌ„vatimÌ£sa heaven tries to persuade the Venerable Anuruddha to aspire for rebirth in her realm, but he declares that he has ended the process of rebirth and will never take another existence. The last sutta in the chapter \(**9:14**\) also occurs in the JaÌ„takas, interestingly with the Bodhisatta in the role played here by the bhikkhu.

## **10. YAKKHASAÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

The yakkhas are fierce spirits inhabiting remote areas such as forests, hills, and abandoned caves. They are depicted as of hideous mien and wrathful temperament, but when given offerings and shown respect they become benign and may protect people rather than harm them. Many of the shrines that dotted the North Indian countryside were built to honour the yakkhas and secure their favours. Though living in misery they have the potential for awakening and can attain the paths and fruits of the spiritual life.

Â 

The suttas in this chapter cover a wide range of topics. What unites them is not so much the content of the verses but their propagational function in showing the Buddha as the invincible sage who, by his skilful means, can tame and transform even the most violent and fearsome ogres, such as SuÌ„ciloma \(**10:3**\) and Ì„Ì£avaka \(**10:12**\). The saÌ£yutta also includes two charming tales of female yakkhas, famished spirits haunting the outskirts of Jetaâ€™s Grove, who are so deeply moved by the Buddhaâ€™s sermons and the chanting of the monks that they turn over a new leaf and become pious lay devotees \(**10:6**, **7**\). In this saÌ£yutta too we find the story of AnaÌ„thapinÌ£dÌ£ikaâ€™s first meeting with the Buddha, which was abetted by friendly advice from a benevolent yakkha \(**10:8**\). In three suttas the yakkhas speak verses in praise of bhikkhunÌ„s \(**10:9â€“11**\).

Â 





## **11. SAKKASAÌ£YUTTA **

Â 

In the early Buddhist pantheon, Sakka is the ruler of the devas in the TaÌ„vatimÌ£sa heaven and also a follower of the Buddha. A long conversation between him and the Buddha, culminating in his attainment of stream-entry, is told in the SakkapaÃ±ha Sutta \(DN No. 20\). This samÌ£yutta does not report the Buddhaâ€™s own encounters with Sakka, but gives \(in the Buddhaâ€™s words\) accounts of Sakkaâ€™s deeds and conversations. The suttas are thus presented as fables, but fables which always embody a moral message. The samÌ£yutta also includes the famous Dhajagga Sutta \(**11:3**\), in which the Buddha commends to the monks recollection of the Three Jewelsâ€”the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the SanÌ‡ghaâ€”as an antidote to fear.

Â 

In Buddhist legend the TaÌ„vatimÌ£sa devas are perpetually being attacked by the asuras, the titans, beings of great physical prowess and violent ambition who seek to conquer them and take control of their domain. The SakkasamÌ£yutta repeatedly pits Sakka in struggle against the leaders of the asuras, Vepacitti and Verocana. The two sides can be read as symbolizing alternative political philosophies. The asura leaders favour rule by force and retaliation against enemies; they rationalize aggression and extol the ethic of â€œmight makes right.â€ Sakka, in contrast, stands for rule by righteousness, patience towards aggressors, and the compassionate treatment of wrongdoers \(**11:4**, **5**, **8**\). Sakka and the devas honour sages and holy men, the asuras scorn them, and thus the sages help the devas but curse the asuras \(**11:9**, **10**\).

Â 

In this samÌ£yutta Sakka appears as the ideal lay devotee. He earned his place as ruler of the devas, while he was still a human being, by fulfilling seven vows which embody the standards of the virtuous householder \(**11:11**\). His understanding of the Buddhaâ€™s excellence is inferior to BrahmÌ„ Sahampatiâ€™s \(**11:17**\), but in three suttas he eloquently proclaims the reasons for his devotion to the Buddha, the SanÌ‡gha, and even devout householders \(**11:18â€“20**\). In the last three suttas, the Buddha holds up Sakkaâ€™s patience and forgiveness as a model for the bhikkhus \(**11:23â€“25**\).

## ***19 \(9\) Childless \(1\)* **

Â 

At SaÌ„vatthiÌ„. Then King Pasenadi of Kosala approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, and sat down to one side. The Blessed One then said to him: â€œWhere are you coming from, great king, in the middle of the day?â€

â€œHere, venerable sir, a financier householder in SaÌ„vatthiÌ„ has died. I have come after conveying his heirless fortune to the palace, as he died intestate.245 There were eighty lakhs of gold, \[90\] not to speak of silver, and yet, venerable sir, that financier householderâ€™s meals were like this: he ate red rice along with sour gruel. His clothes were like this: he wore a three-piece hempen garment. His vehicle was like this: <202> he went about in a dilapidated little cart with a leaf awning.â€246

â€œSo it is, great king\! So it is, great king\! At SaÌ„vatthiÌ„. Then King Pasenadi of Kosala approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, and sat down to one side. The Blessed One then said to him: <210>

â€œAnd how, great king, is a person one heading from light to darkness? As the fruit of this final deed of merit, all the men were immediately reborn in the TaÌ„vatimÌ£sa heaven in a single group with their leader at the head. 88 I read with Se: *Passa samaÌ„dhiá¹ƒ subhaÌ„vitaá¹ƒ cittaÃ± ca suvimuttaá¹ƒ na caÌ„bhinataá¹ƒ na caÌ„panataá¹ƒ na ca sasanÌ‡khaÌ„raniggayhavaÌ„ritavataá¹ƒ* . The PaÌ„li phrase is extremely difficult and the exact reading uncertain. Indeed, in the Central Asian Skt ms corresponding to DN III 279,4 \(Waldschmidt, *Sanskrittexte aus den Turfanfunden* IV, p. 70, V.8 \(3\)\), it is conspicuously absent. A Skt version in SÌraÌ„v-bh \(p. 444,19-21\) reads *vaÌ„rivad dhrÌ£taá¹ƒ*, â€œmaintained like water,â€ which seems to me unlikely to correspond to the original reading.

Â 

Ee1 puts a hiatus after *niggayha*, and Ee2 separates it off entirely; the other eds. integrate *niggayha* into the long compound. There is no way to determine, on the basis of grammar alone, which is correct. Each attempt to resolve the expression into its elements gives rise to its own special problems, and even the *atÌ£tÌ£hakathaÌ„s* and *tÌ£Ä«kaÌ„s* offer conflicting explanations, e.g., Sv III 1060,11-13 and Vibh-a 421,13-15 take *niggayha* to be absolutive \(as does Spk\) and turn *vaÌ„rita* into the absolutive *vaÌ„retvaÌ„*; their respective *tÌ£Ä«kaÌ„s*, Sv-ptÌ£ III 284,24-27 \(Be\) and Vibh-mtÌ£ 205,16-18 \(Be\), take *niggayha* as the gerundive *niggahetabba* and *vaÌ„rita* as the gerundive *vaÌ„retabba*. Since *niggayha* occurs elsewhere unambiguously as an absolutive \(e.g., at MN III 118,4, interestingly, as here, without a direct object\), while there seem to be no instances in canonical PaÌ„li of the word occurring as a gerundive, the *atÌ£tÌ£hakathaÌ„s* are more likely to be right. Norman questions this interpretation on the ground that there is no other known instance in PaÌ„li of an absolutive occurring as the second member of a compound \(personal communication\), but perhaps we should not rule out the possibility that we have such a construction here. I translate, however, in compliance with natural English idiom rather than in strict conformity with the syntax of the PaÌ„li.

Â 

Readings of the last part of the compound vary among the different traditions: in general *vaÌ„ritavata* prevails in the Sinhalese tradition, *vaÌ„ritagata* in the Burmese,with Burmese vv.ll. *vaÌ„rivaÌ„vata* and *vaÌ„rivaÌ„vatÌ£a* also recorded. *VaÌ„rita* here is a past participle of the causative *vaÌ„reti*, to block, to restrain. The terminal member of the compound could then be either *vata* or *gata*. *Gata* is clearly a past participle. *Vata* is more problematic. At KS 1:39, *vaÌ„ritavataá¹ƒ* is rendered â€œhaving the habit of self-denial.â€ Apparently C.Rh.D understands *vata* as equivalent to Skt *vrata* . However, Spkâ€™s gloss, *chinnattaÌ„ vataá¹ƒ phalasamaÌ„dhinaÌ„ samaÌ„hitaá¹ƒ*, suggests that we have a past participle here, and I would propose that *vata* represents Skt *vrÌ£ta*, which according to MW can mean â€œstopped, checked, held back.â€ I cannot cite other occurrences of the simple participle *vata* in PaÌ„li, but prefixed forms are common enough: *saá¹ƒvuta*, *nibbuta*, *vivatÌ£a*, *aÌ„vatÌ£a*, etc. Thus we would have here two past participles from the same root, one causative, the other simple, so that the compound *vaÌ„ritavata* would mean â€œblocked and checkedâ€ \(unfortunately two distinct English verbs are needed to capture the nuances\). Although this construction is certainly unusual, it need not be rejected out of hand, as it may have been used for special emphasis. If the reading *gata* is accepted, *vaÌ„ritagata* could mean â€œgone to \(attained to\) control,â€ with *varita* taken as a noun of state. This certainly sounds more natural than *vaÌ„ritavata*, but the prevalence of *vata* in the textual tradition lends strong support to its authenticity.
